revision.comment: Fix prefpunct and using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
A '''Sverdrup wave''' (also known as Poincaré wave, or rotational gravity wave <ref name="kundu">Kundu, P. K., and L. M. Cohen. "Fluid mechanics, 638 pp." Academic, Calif (1990).</ref>) is a wave in the ocean, which is affected by gravity and Earth's rotation (see [[Coriolis effect]]).
For a non-rotating fluid, shallow water waves are affected only by gravity (see [[Gravity wave]]), where the [[phase velocity]] of shallow water gravity wave (''c'') can be noted as : <math>c = (gH)^{1/2} </math>
and the group velocity (''c''<sub>g</sub>) of shallow water gravity wave can be noted as : <math>c_\mathrm{g}=(gH)^{1/2}</math> i.e. <math>c=c_\mathrm{g}</math>
where ''g'' is gravity, ''λ'' is the [[wavelength]] and ''H'' is the total depth.
== Derivation == When the fluid is rotating, gravity waves with a long enough wavelength (discussed below) will also be affected by rotational forces. The linearized, shallow-water equations with a constant rotation rate, ''f<sub>0</sub>'', are <ref name="vallis">Vallis, Geoffrey K. Atmospheric and oceanic fluid dynamics: fundamentals and large-scale circulation. Cambridge University Press, 2006.</ref> : <math> \frac{\partial u}{\partial t} - f_0v = -g\frac{\partial h}{\partial x},</math> : <math> \frac{\partial v}{\partial t} + f_0u = -g\frac{\partial h}{\partial y},</math> : <math> \frac{\partial h}{\partial t} + H(u_x+v_y) = 0,</math> where ''u'' and ''v'' are the horizontal velocities and ''h'' is the instantaneous height of the free surface. Using Fourier analysis, these equations can be combined to find the [[dispersion relation]] for Sverdrup waves: : <math> \omega^2 = f_0^2 + gH(k^2 + l^2), </math> where ''k'' and ''l'' are the wavenumbers associated with the horizontal and vertical directions, and <math> \omega </math> is the frequency of oscillation.
== Limiting Cases == There are two primary modes of interest when considering Poincaré waves:<ref name="kundu" /><ref name="vallis" /> * Short wave limit : <math> (k^2 + l^2) \gg \frac{f_0^2}{gH} \qquad \textrm{or} \qquad (k^2+l^2) \gg L_D^{-1}, </math> where <math> L_D = \frac{(gH)^{1/2}}{f_0} </math> is the [[Rossby radius of deformation]]. In this limit, the dispersion relation reduces to the solution for a non-rotating gravity wave. * Long wave limit : <math> (k^2 + l^2) \ll \frac{f_0^2}{gH} \qquad \textrm{or} \qquad (k^2+l^2) \ll L_D^{-1}, </math> which looks like inertial oscillations driven purely by rotational forces.
=== Solution for the one-dimensional case === For a wave traveling in one direction (<math> l = 0 </math>), the horizontal velocities are found to be equal to : <math> u = \frac{\omega}{kH}H_0cos(kx-\omega t) </math> : <math> v = \frac{f_0}{kH}H_0sin(kx-\omega t). </math> This shows that the inclusion of rotation will cause the wave to develop oscillations at 90° to the wave propagation at the opposite phase. In general, these are elliptical orbits that depend on the relative strength of gravity and rotation. In the long wave limit, these are circular orbits characterized by inertial oscillations.
== References == <references />
==See also== *[[Kelvin wave]] *[[Rossby wave]] *[[Geophysical fluid dynamics]] *[[Sverdrup]] *[[Harald Sverdrup (oceanographer)|Harald Sverdrup]]
[[Category:Waves]]

revision.comment: Reverted 1 edit by [[Special:Contributions/182.255.118.78|182.255.118.78]] ([[User talk:182.255.118.78|talk]]) to last revision by Bender the Bot. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
:''For the implement, see [[Kitchen_knife#Bread_knife]].'' {{coord|30|3|S|150|3|E|display=title}} [[Image:The Breadknife.jpg|thumb|right|250px|View of The Breadknife]]
'''The Breadknife''' is a [[Dike (geology)|volcanic dyke]] in [[New South Wales]], Australia. It is nearly 90 metres high,<ref name="wac">{{cite web |url=http://www.australiangeographic.com.au/travel/destinations/2014/05/warrumbungles-a-climbers-paradise |title=Warrumbungles: a climber's paradise |author=Ken Eastwood |date=9 May 2014 |work=Australian Geographic |publisher= |accessdate=25 August 2014 }}</ref> but often is only 4 m wide, which is particularly rare. The Breadknife was part of a large [[shield volcano]], that first erupted about 17 million years ago and stopped about 13 million years ago.<ref name="goa">{{cite book |title=The Geology of Australia |last=David |first=Johnson |year=2009 |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0521767415 |page=191 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=RSIbLENyT2wC |accessdate=7 November 2012 }}</ref> It is composed of [[Peralkaline rock|peralkaline]] [[trachyte]].<ref name="ivieaanz"/>
Nearby volcanic remnants include the Belougery Spire, Belougery Split Rock, Crater Bluff, Bluff Mountain and Mount Exmouth. A network of walking tracks are used to access the steep mountains and ridges surrounding the dyke. The shortest walk completely around the Breadknife is hard and steep, taking roughly five hours to complete.
==Origins== A huge shield-shaped volcano formed as volcanic explosions occurred over millions of years. This shield volcano rose about 1,000 m and is now largely eroded, forming the [[Warrumbungles]].<ref name="ivieaanz">{{cite book |title=Intraplate Volcanism in Eastern Australia and New Zealand |last=Duggan |first=M B |chapter=Northern New South Wales: Warrumbungle |year=1989 |editor1-last=Johnson |editor1-first=R. Wally |editor2-last=Knutson |editor2-first=Jan |editor3-last=Taylor |editor3-first=Stuart Ross |editor4-last=Australian Academy of Science |publisher=Cambridge University Press |isbn=0521380839 |page=121 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4NBOn7ecZeAC |accessdate=25 August 2014}}</ref> The Breadknife was formed when hot [[magma]] spread through a soft rock. When the magma solidified and became harder than the soft rock, erosion exposed a dyke.
==In popular culture== The village in the Animated series [[Adventures of the Little Koala]] took place within the shadow of the Breadknife.
==See also== {{Portal|New South Wales}} *[[List of volcanoes in Australia]] *[[Warrumbungle National Park]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Breadknife, The}} [[Category:Volcanism of Australia]] [[Category:Extinct volcanism]] [[Category:Miocene volcanism]] [[Category:Intrusions]]
{{NewSouthWales-geo-stub}}

revision.comment: Updated the site. The current "handlingsregel" is 3% not the 4% (which it said before my change. I also added a small paragraph talking about the change.
revision.text:
[[File:Handlingsregelen.png|thumbnail|Drawing showing oil income versus how it is used under the budgetary rule]] '''The budgetary rule'''<ref>http://www.aftenbladet.no/energi/aenergy/Record-oil-revenues-2558183.html#.Ufei3m08l8o</ref> ({{lang-no|handlingsregelen}}) is a rule concerning the usage of [[capital gain]]s from [[The Government Pension Fund of Norway#The Government Pension Fund – Global|The Government Pension Fund - Global]] of [[Norway]]. The rule states that a maximum of 3% of the fund's value should be allocated to the yearly [[government budget]]. Its main stated justification is to avoid the [[Dutch disease]] in the Norwegian economy due to the large influx of oil-sourced revenue.
The rule was introduced in 2001 during the [[First cabinet Stoltenberg|First cabinet]] [[Jens Stoltenberg|Stoltenberg]], and has a broad cross-party support.
The rule was last changed from 4% to 3% february 2017. Every party in the parliament was in favour of the change, except the right wing [[Progress Party (Norway)]].
==References== <references />
==External links==
* [http://www.regjeringen.no/en/dep/fin/Selected-topics/the-government-pension-fund.html?id=1441 About the government pension fund], from the Norwegian government
{{DEFAULTSORT:budgetary rule}} [[Category:Energy economics]] [[Category:Energy in Norway]] [[Category:Public finance of Norway]] [[Category:2001 introductions]] [[Category:2001 establishments in Norway]]
{{Norway-stub}}

revision.text:
{{distinguish|Trinidad (disambiguation)}} {{Infobox Islands | name = Trindade and Martin Vaz Archipelago | image_name = Simone_Marinho_-_Trindade_-_2010_05_08_edited.jpg | image_caption = Rocky cliffs of Trindade Island | image_size = | map_image = Location Trindade and Martim Vaz Archipelago.png | map_caption = | native_name_link = Portuguese language | sobriquet = | location = [[Atlantic Ocean]] | coordinates = {{coord|20|31|30|S|29|19|30|W|display=inline,title}} | archipelago = ''Arquipélago de Trindade e Martin Vaz'' | total_islands = 5 | major_islands = Trindade; Martin Vaz | area_km2 = 10.4 <!-- | area = {{convert|10.4|km2|sqmi|lk=out|abbr=on}} --> | rank = | length_km = | width_km = | coastline_km = | highest_mount = Pico do Desejado<ref>[http://www1.folha.uol.com.br/folha/turismo/aventura/ilha_da_trindade-infograficos.shtml Ilha da Trindade - Infográficos e mapas] [[Folha de S.Paulo]]. Retrieved on 6 June 2009.</ref> | elevation_m = 620 <!-- | elevation = {{convert|620|m|ft|lk=out|abbr=on}} --> | country = [[Brazil]] | country_admin_divisions_title = Region | country_admin_divisions = [[Southeast Region, Brazil|Southeast]] | country_admin_divisions_title_1 = State | country_admin_divisions_1 = [[Espírito Santo]] | country_admin_divisions_title_2 = Administration | country_admin_divisions_2 = [[Brazilian Navy|1st Naval District of the Brazilian Navy]] | population = 32 | population_as_of = 2009 | density_km2 = | ethnic_groups = | website = [https://www.marinha.mil.br/com1dn/poit Brazilian Navy First Naval District] | additional_info = }}
'''Trindade and Martin Vaz'''<ref>National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency Web: http://geonames.nga.mil/namesgaz/</ref> ({{lang-pt|Trindade e Martim Vaz}}, {{IPA-pt|tɾĩˈdadʒi i mɐʁˈtʃĩ ˈvas|pron}}) is an [[archipelago]] located in the Southern [[Atlantic Ocean]] about {{convert|1,100|km|mi|abbr=off}} east of the coast of [[Espírito Santo]], [[Brazil]], which it constitutes a part of. The archipelago has a total area of {{convert|10.4|km2|1|abbr=off}} and a population of 32 ([[Brazilian Navy]] personnel).{{citation needed|date=October 2015}} The archipelago consists of five islands and several rocks and stacks; Trindade is the largest island, with an area of {{convert|10.1|km2|1|abbr=off}}; about {{convert|49|km|mi|abbr=off}} east of it are the tiny Martin Vaz islets, with a total area of {{convert|0.3|km2|ha|1|lk=out|abbr=off}} .
The islands are of [[Volcano|volcanic]] origin and have rugged terrain. They are largely barren, except for the southern part of Trindade. They were discovered in 1502 by [[Portugal|Portuguese]] explorer [[Estêvão da Gama (c. 1470)|Estêvão da Gama]] and stayed Portuguese until they became part of Brazil at its [[Independence of Brazil|independence in 1822]]. From 1895 to 1896, Trindade was occupied by the [[United Kingdom]] until an agreement with Brazil was reached. During the period of British occupation, Trindade was known as "South Trinidad."
The islands are situated some {{convert|2,100|km|mi|abbr=off}} southwest of [[Ascension Island]] and {{convert|2,550|km|mi|abbr=off}} west of [[Saint Helena]], while the distance to the west coast of [[Africa]] is {{convert|4,270|km|mi|abbr=off}}.
==Geography== The individual islands with their respective locations are given in the following:
*'''Ilha da Trindade''' (Portuguese for "Trinity Island") ({{coord|20|31|30|S|29|19|30|W|region:BR-ES_type:isle}}) *'''Ilhas de Martim Vaz''' ({{coord|20|30|00|S|28|51|00|W|region:BR-ES_type:isle}}) **'''Ilha do Norte''' ("North Island"), {{convert|300|m|ft|abbr=off}} north-northwest of Ilha da Racha, {{convert|75|m|ft|abbr=off}} high. ({{coord|20|30|00|S|28|51|00|W|region:BR-ES_type:isle}}) **'''Ilha da Racha''' ("Crack Island") or '''Ilha Martim Vaz''', the largest, {{convert|175|m|ft|abbr=off}} high near the northwest end. The shores are strewn with boulders. ({{coord|20|30|18|S|29|20|42|W|region:BR-ES_type:isle}}) **'''Rochedo da Agulha''' ("Needle Rock"), a flat circular rock {{convert|200|m|ft|abbr=off}} northwest of Ilha da Racha, is {{convert|60|m|ft|abbr=off}} high. **'''Ilha do Sul''' ("South Island"), {{convert|1,600|m|ft|abbr=off}} south of Ilha da Racha, is a rocky pinnacle. Ilha do Sul is the easternmost point of Brazil. ({{coord|20|31|00|S|28|51|00|W|region:BR-ES_type:isle}})
=== Trindade === [[File:Martin Vaz.png|thumb|left|NASA satellite imagery of Martin Vaz Islands in [[False-color|pseudo-color]].]] The small island of '''Trindade''', with an area of 10.3 km², lies at the eastern end of an E-W-trending chain of [[submarine volcanoes]] and [[guyot]]s extending about 1,000 km (620 mi) from the continental shelf off the Brazilian coast. The island lies more than halfway between Brazil and the [[Mid-Atlantic Ridge]] near the eastern end of the submarine [[Vitória-Trindade Ridge]].
Trindade is a mountainous, desiccated volcanic island with numerous phonolitic lava domes and steep-sided volcanic plugs. The highest summit is Pico Desejado, near the center, {{convert|620|m|ft|abbr=off}} high. Nearby to the northwest are Pico da Trindade ({{convert|590|m|ft|abbr=on}}) and Pico Bonifácio ({{convert|570|m|ft|abbr=on}}). Pico Monumento, a remarkable peak in the form of a slightly inclined cylinder, rises from the west coast to {{convert|270|m|ft|abbr=on}}. The youngest volcanism, at Vulcão do Paredão ({{convert|217|m|ft|abbr=on}}) on the southeast tip of the island, constructed a [[pyroclastic flows|pyroclastic]] cone with lava flows that are no older than the [[Holocene]] (Almeida, 1961). Remnants of the crater of the {{convert|200|m|ft|adj=mid|abbr=off|-high}} cinder cone are still preserved. Lava flows traveled from the cone to the north, where they formed an irregular shoreline and offshore islands. Smaller volcanic centers of the latest volcanic stage are found in the Morro Vermelho ({{convert|515|m|ft|abbr=on}}) area in the south-central part of the island.
Until 1850, the island was covered 85% of its length by a forest of ''[[Colubrina]] glandulosa'' trees, 15m in height and 40 cm trunk diameter. The introduction of non-native animals like goats, pigs, sheep, etc. and the indiscriminate cutting of trees led to total [[Local extinction|extirpation]] of the same, causing heavy erosion throughout the island with a loss of about 1 to 2 meter of fertile soils. The effect of this devastation impaired the flow of water streams, with the depletion of several springs.
There is a small settlement in the north on the shore of a cove called Enseada dos Portugueses, supporting a garrison of the Brazilian Navy, 32 strong.
The archipelago is the main nesting site of the [[green sea turtle]] in Brazil. There are also large numbers of breeding seabirds, including the endemic subspecies of the [[Great frigatebird]] (''Fregata minor nicolli'') and [[Lesser frigatebird]] (''F. ariel trinitatis''), and it is only Atlantic breeding site for the [[Trindade petrel]].<ref>Fund, W. 2014. [http://www.eoearth.org/view/article/156706/ Trinidade-Martin Vaz Islands tropical forests]</ref> [[Humpback whale]]s have been confirmed to use the Trindade island as a nursery.<ref>Siciliano S., Heissler L.V., Ilha B.E., Wickert C.J., Moura F. de J., Moreno B.I., 2016, [https://archive.iwc.int/pages/search.php?search=!collection24457&bc_from=themes Humpback whales off Trindade Island, Brazil: the last piece of the puzzle is in place?], SC66-b-SH-02, [[International Whaling Commission]] scientific reports, Retrieved on August 11, 2016</ref>
== History == {{ref-improve|date=June 2017}} === 16th to 18th century === The Trindade and Martin Vaz Islands were discovered in 1502 by [[Portugal|Portuguese]] navigators led by [[Estêvão da Gama (c.1470)|Estêvão da Gama]], and, along with Brazil, became part of the [[Portuguese Empire]].
Many visitors have been to Martin Vaz, the most famous of whom was the English astronomer [[Edmund Halley]], who took possession of the island on behalf of the [[Monarchy of the United Kingdom|British Monarchy]] in 1700. Wild goats and hogs, descendants of ones set free by Halley, were still found on Martin Vaz in 1939.<ref>National Geographic Magazine annotated map of Atlantic Ocean, dated July 1939</ref>
{{HMS|Rattlesnake|1777|6}}, a 198-ton, 12-gun [[Cutter (boat)|cutter]]-rigged [[sloop]], was wrecked on Trindade on 21 October 1781, shortly after Commander [[Philippe d'Auvergne]] had taken over command. ''Rattlesnake'' had been ordered to survey the island to ascertain whether it would make a useful base for outward-bound [[Indiamen]]. She anchored, but that evening the wind increased and by seven o’clock she was dragging. Two hours later the first cable parted and Commander d’Auvergne [[Anchor#Club hauling|club-hauled]] his way out, setting main and fore sails, and using the remaining anchor cable as a spring. This successfully put ''Rattlesnake''’s head to seaward. The remaining cable was then cut, and the sloop wore round and stood out to sea. However the ground now shallowed quite rapidly and suddenly ''Rattlesnake'' struck a submerged rock. She started filling with water, so, in order to preserve the lives of the crew, d'Auvergne ran her ashore. [[George Johnstone (Royal Navy officer)|Commodore Johnstone]] on board {{HMS|Jupiter|1778|6}} had previously wished to colonise the island and claim it for Britain, so d'Auvergne agreed to stay on the tiny island with 30 sailors, 20 captured French sailors, one French woman, some animals and supplies. They were resupplied by another ship in January 1782, then they appear to have been forgotten, as they lived on the tiny island for a year until {{HMS|Bristol|1775|6}} and a convoy of Indiamen, which fortuitously called there, rescued them in late December 1782.<ref name="JAitES">{{cite book |first=Jane |last=Ashelford |title=In the English Service: The Life of Philippe D'Auvergne |publisher=Jersey Heritage Trust |ISBN=978-0955250880}}</ref>{{rp|40–45}}
Captain [[Jean-François de Galaup, comte de La Pérouse|La Pérouse]] stopped there at the outset of his 1785 voyage to the Pacific.
=== 19th to 20th century === In 1889, [[Edward Frederick Knight]] went treasure hunting on the island. He was unsuccessful but he wrote a detailed description of the island and his expedition, titled ''[[The Cruise of the Alerte]]''.
In 1893 another American, [[James Harden-Hickey]], claimed the island and declared himself as James I, Prince of [[Principality of Trinidad|Trinidad]].<ref>"To Be Prince of Trinidad: He Is Baron Harden-Hickey", ''[[New York Tribune]]'', November 5, 1893, p 1</ref><ref>[http://www.nypress.com/15/50/news&columns/oldsmoke.cfm Bryk, William, "News & Columns", ''New York Press'', v 15 no 50 (December 10, 2002)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060430105931/http://www.nypress.com/15/50/news%26columns/oldsmoke.cfm |date=April 30, 2006 }}</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1894/06/10/archives/principality-of-trinidad-john-h-flaglera-soninlaw-is-its-sovereign.html "Principality of Trinidad: John H. Flagler's Son-in-Law Is Its Sovereign, Self-Proclaimed as James I", ''[[New York Times]]'', June 10, 1894, p 23]</ref> According to James Harden-Hickey's plans, Trinidad, after being recognized as an independent country, would become a [[military dictatorship]] and have him as dictator.<ref name="Bryk 2002">[http://www.nypress.com/15/50/news&columns/oldsmoke.cfm Bryk (2002)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060430105931/http://www.nypress.com/15/50/news%26columns/oldsmoke.cfm |date=2006-04-30 }}</ref> He designed [[postage stamps]], a [[national flag]], and a [[coat of arms]]; established a [[chivalric order]], the "Cross of Trinidad"; bought a [[schooner]] to transport [[colonist]]s; appointed [[M. le Comte de la Boissiere]] as [[Secretary of State]]; opened a [[consular office]] at 217 [[36th Street (Manhattan)|West 36th Street]] in [[New York City]]; and even issued [[government bonds]] to finance construction of [[infrastructure]] on the island. Despite his plans, his idea was ridiculed or ignored by the world.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1895/08/01/archives/trinidads-prince-awake-an-appeal-to-washington-against-brazil-and.html "Trinidad's Prince Awake: An Appeal to Washington Against Brazil and Great Britain", ''New York Times'', August 1, 1895, p 1]</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1895/08/02/archives/grand-chancellor-of-trinidad-significant-phases-in-the-ascent-of.html "Grand Chancellor of Trinidad: Significant Phases in the Ascent of Male Comte de la Boissiere to His Elevated Diplomatic Post", ''New York Times'', August 2, 1895, p 9]</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1895/08/07/archives/trinidads-case-in-washington-courteously-the-chancellor-would.html "Trinidad's Case in Washington: Courteously, the Chancellor Would Permit Britain's Cable Station and Use It, but There Is Graver Trouble", ''New York Times'', August 7, 1895, p 1]</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1895/08/09/archives/trinidads-diplomat-in-action-m-de-la-boissiere-asks-that-his.html "Trinidad's Diplomat in Action: M. de la Boissiere Asks that His Sovereign's Land Be Recognized as a Neutral Principality", ''New York Times'', August 9, 1895, p 5]</ref><ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/1896/01/24/archives/no-use-for-staten-isle-controller-fitch-and-corporation-coun-sel.html "Trinidad's Prince at Work: Grand Chancellor de la Boissiere Tells How the War Between Great Britain and Brazil Will Be Averted", ''New York Times'', Jan 24, 1896, p 9]</ref> <ref>[http://www.crwflags.com/fotw/flags/br-trin.html Flags of the World - Trindade and Martins Vaz Islands (Brazil)] (''sic'')</ref>
In July 1895, the [[United Kingdom|British]] again tried to take possession of this strategic position in the [[Atlantic]].<ref name="Bryk 2002"/> The British planned to use the island as a cable station.<ref name="Bryk 2002"/> However, Brazilian diplomatic efforts, along with Portuguese support{{Citation needed|date=March 2008}}, reinstated Trindade Island to Brazilian sovereignty.
In order to clearly demonstrate sovereignty over the island, now part of the State of [[Espírito Santo]] and the municipality of [[Vitória, Brazil|Vitória]], a landmark was built on January 24, 1897. Nowadays, Brazilian presence is marked by a permanent [[Brazilian Navy]] base on the main island.
In July 1910 the ship ''[[Terra Nova (ship)|Terra Nova]]'' carrying the last [[Terra Nova Expedition|expedition]] of Captain [[Robert Falcon Scott]] to the Antarctic arrived at the island, at the time uninhabited. Some members of the Scott's expedition explored the island with scientific purposes, and a description of it is included in ''[[The Worst Journey in the World]]'', by [[Apsley Cherry-Garrard]], one of the members of the expedition.
In August 1914, the [[Imperial German Navy]] established a supply base for its warships off Trindade. On September 14, 1914, the [[Royal Navy]] [[auxiliary cruiser]] {{HMS|Carmania}} fought the German {{SMS|Cap Trafalgar}} off Trindade in the [[Battle of Trindade]]. ''Carmania'' sank ''Cap Trafalgar'', but sustained severe damage herself.{{citation needed|date=September 2015}}

revision.comment: /* Problem */
revision.text:
{{more footnotes|date=April 2016}} [[File:Black body.svg|thumb|303px|The ultraviolet catastrophe is the error at short wavelengths in the [[Rayleigh–Jeans law]] (depicted as "classical theory" in the graph) for the energy emitted by an ideal black-body. The error, much more pronounced for short wavelengths, is the difference between the black curve (as classically predicted by the [[Rayleigh–Jeans law]]) and the blue curve (the measured curve as predicted by [[Planck's law]]).]]
The '''ultraviolet catastrophe''', also called the '''Rayleigh–Jeans catastrophe''', was the prediction of late 19th century/early 20th century [[classical physics]] that an ideal [[black body]] at [[thermal equilibrium]] will emit [[radiation]] in all frequency ranges, emitting more energy as the frequency increases. By calculating the total amount of radiated energy (i.e., the sum of emissions in all frequency ranges), it can be shown that a blackbody would release an infinite amount of energy, contradicting the principles of [[conservation of energy]] and indicating that a new model for the behaviour of blackbodies was needed.
The term "ultraviolet catastrophe" was first used in 1911 by [[Paul Ehrenfest]], but the concept originated with the 1900 derivation of the [[Rayleigh–Jeans law]]. The phrase refers to the fact that the Rayleigh–Jeans law accurately predicts experimental results at radiative frequencies below 10<sup>5</sup> GHz, but begins to diverge with empirical observations as these frequencies reach the [[ultraviolet]] region of the [[electromagnetic spectrum]].<ref>{{cite book |last1=McQuarrie |first1=Donald A. |last2=Simon |first2=John D. |title=Physical chemistry: a molecular approach |date=1997 |publisher=Univ. Science Books |location=Sausalito, Calif. |isbn=978-0-935702-99-6 |edition=rev. }}</ref> Since the first appearance of the term, it has also been used for other predictions of a similar nature, as in [[quantum electrodynamics]] and such cases as [[ultraviolet divergence]].
== Problem == The ultraviolet catastrophe results from the [[equipartition theorem]] of classical [[statistical mechanics]] which states that all [[harmonic oscillator]] modes (degrees of freedom) of a system at equilibrium have an average energy of <math>kT</math>.
An example, from Mason's ''A History of the Sciences'',<ref>{{cite book | last = Mason | first = Stephen F. | title = A History of the Sciences | publisher = Collier Books | year = 1962 | page = 550}}</ref> illustrates multi-mode vibration via a piece of string. As a [[Standing wave|natural vibrator]], the string will oscillate with [[Overtone#Explanation|specific modes]] (the standing waves of a string in harmonic resonance), dependent on the length of the string. In classical physics, a radiator of energy will act as a natural vibrator. And, since each mode will have the same energy, most of the energy in a natural vibrator will be in the smaller wavelengths and higher frequencies, where most of the modes are.
According to classical electromagnetism, the number of electromagnetic modes in a 3-dimensional cavity, per unit frequency, is proportional to the square of the frequency. This therefore implies that the radiated power per unit frequency should follow the Rayleigh–Jeans law, and be proportional to frequency squared. Thus, both the power at a given frequency and the total radiated power is unlimited as higher and higher frequencies are considered: this is clearly unphysical as the total radiated power of a cavity is not observed to be infinite, a point that was made independently by [[Albert Einstein|Einstein]] and by [[Lord Rayleigh]] and Sir [[James Jeans]] in 1905.
== Solution == [[Max Planck]] derived the correct form for the intensity spectral distribution function by making some strange (for the time) assumptions. In particular, Planck assumed that electromagnetic radiation can be emitted or absorbed only in discrete packets, called quanta, of energy: <math>E_\text{quanta}=h\nu=h\frac{c}{\lambda}</math>, where ''h'' is [[Planck's constant]]. Planck's assumptions led to the correct form of the spectral distribution functions: <math>B_\lambda(\lambda, T) =\frac{2 hc^2}{\lambda^5} \frac{1}{e^{h c/(\lambda k_\mathrm{B}T)} - 1}</math>. [[Albert Einstein]] and [[Satyendra Nath Bose]] solved the problem by postulating that Planck's quanta were real physical particles — what we now call [[photon]]s, not just a mathematical fiction. They modified [[statistical mechanics]] in the style of [[Boltzmann]] to an ensemble of photons. Einstein's photon had an energy proportional to its frequency and also explained an unpublished law of Stokes and the [[photoelectric effect]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Einstein and the Quantum |first=A. Douglas |last=Stone |publisher=Princeton University Press |year=2013}}</ref> This published postulate was specifically cited by the [[Nobel Prize in Physics]] committee in their decision to award the [[List of Nobel laureates in Physics|prize for 1921]] to Einstein.<ref name="Nobel">{{cite web |url=https://www.nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/physics/laureates/1921/ |title=The Nobel Prize in Physics: 1921 |author=<!--Not stated--> |date=2017 |website=Nobelprize.org |publisher=Nobel Media AB |access-date=December 13, 2017 |quote=For his services to Theoretical Physics, and especially for his discovery of the law of the photoelectric effect.}}</ref>
== See also == *[[Wien approximation]] *[[Vacuum catastrophe]]
== References == {{reflist}}
== Further reading == *{{cite book | authorlink=Herbert Kroemer |last=Kroemer |first= Herbert |author2=Kittel, Charles | title=Thermal Physics |edition=2 | publisher=W. H. Freeman Company | year=1980 | isbn=0-7167-1088-9 | chapter=Chapter 4 }} *{{cite book | authorlink=Claude Cohen-Tannoudji |last=Cohen-Tannoudji |first=Claude |last2=Diu |first2=Bernard |last3=Laloë |last4=Franck | year=1977 | title=Quantum Mechanics: Volume One | publisher=Hermann, Paris | isbn=0-471-16433-X | pages=624–626}}

revision.comment: {{convert|1000|ft}} --- > {{convert|1500|ft}} , source: https://www.livescience.com/63614-great-white-sharks-lair.html
revision.text:
[[File:White shark café map.png|thumb|right|The White Shark Café, in between the Guadalupe Islands and the Hawaii islands.]] The '''White Shark Café''' is a remote mid-[[Pacific Ocean]] area noted as a winter and spring habitat of otherwise coastal [[great white shark]]s.
The area, halfway between [[Baja California]] and [[Hawaii]], received its unofficial name in 2002 from researchers at [[Leland Stanford Junior University|Stanford University]]'s [[Hopkins Marine Station]] who were studying the great white shark species using [[Satellite tracking (animal migration)|satellite tracking]] tags.<ref name="Thomas">{{cite news |url=http://articles.latimes.com/2006/sep/29/sports/sp-outdoors29 |title=The Great White Way: Scientists are excited by research that shows these dangerous ocean predators make a winter pilgrimage to a vast offshore destination between Baja California and Hawaii called the White Shark Café. |author=Thomas, Pete |date=September 29, 2006 |newspaper=[[Los Angeles Times]] |accessdate=2007-07-18}}</ref> They identified a zone with a radius of approximately {{convert|250|km|mi}} centered at approximately {{coord|23.37|-132.71||display=inline,title}}.{{sfn|Jorgensen et al|2010}} The findings, which were initially published in the January 3, 2002 issue of the journal [[Nature (journal)|''Nature'']], showed three of four tagged sharks traveled to the Café during a six-month period after they were tagged off the central coast of California.<ref name=Nature-02>{{cite journal |url=http://www.toppcensus.org/web/PublicationDetails.aspx?id=3 |title=Satellite tagging: Expanded niche for white sharks |last1=Boustany |first1=Andre M. |last2=Davis |first2=Scott F. |last3=Pyle |first3=Peter |last4=Anderson |first4=Scot D. |last5=Le Boeuf |first5=Burney J. |last6=Block |first6=Barbara A. |journal=Nature |volume=415 |pages=35–36 |date=2002 |doi=10.1038/415035b |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003033842/http://www.toppcensus.org/web/PublicationDetails.aspx?id=3 |archivedate=3 October 2006 |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref>
Although the area had not previously been suspected as a shark habitat, when mapping the satellite tracking data, researchers discovered that members of the species frequently travel to and loiter in the area.<ref name=Nature-02 /> It was once believed the area has very little food for the animals (researchers described it as the shark equivalent of a [[desert]]),<ref name="Thomas"/><ref name=TOPP-tags /> but research in early 2018 by the vessel ''Falkor'' showed that there is a rich and diverse food chain too deep to be detected by satellites that provides a potentially abundant food supply for the sharks.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/thetwo-way/2018/05/28/613394086/great-white-sharks-have-a-secret-cafe-and-they-led-scientists-right-to-it |title=Great White Sharks Have A Secret 'Cafe,' And They Led Scientists Right To It |author=Kennedy, Merrit |date=28 May 2018 |work=NPR |accessdate=4 July 2018}}</ref> Male, female, and juvenile great whites have been tracked there.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/science/2006-10-22-shark-research_x.htm?POE=TECISVA |title=Little shark helps pierce great white mystery |author=Ritter, John |date=October 23, 2006 |publisher=[[USA TODAY]] |accessdate=2007-07-18}}</ref>
The sharks tracked to the area came from diverse [[rookeries]] along the [[North America]]n coast. They typically took up to 100 days to arrive, traveling around {{convert|1|m/s|abbr=on}}, during which they make periodic dives as deep as {{convert|3000|ft}}. While at the Café, they dive to depths of {{convert|1500|ft}} as often as once every ten minutes.<ref name="Thomas"/>
By 2006, researchers had observed consistent migration and other behavior. Tracking data indicates that white sharks will leave feeding grounds near the coast in winter, travel to the Café, and some may even summer near Hawaii. But many linger in the Café, often for months, before returning to the coast in the fall, coinciding with the [[elephant seal]] breeding season (a favored prey).<ref name=TOPP-tags>{{cite web |url=http://www.toppcensus.org/Web/FeatureDetails.aspx?id=81&WG=10 |title=TOPP Tags Pop Up at the White Shark Cafe |date= |publisher=Tagging of Pacific Pelagics |accessdate=2007-07-18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061003035412/http://www.toppcensus.org/Web/FeatureDetails.aspx?id=81&WG=10 |archivedate=3 October 2006 |deadurl=yes}}</ref>
== Notes == {{reflist}}
==Sources== * {{Cite journal |last1=Jorgensen |first1=SJ |last2=Reeb |first2=CA |last3=Chapple |first3=TK |last4=Anderson |first4=S |last5=Perle |first5=C |date=2010 |title=Philopatry and Migration of Pacific White Sharks |journal=Proceedings of the Royal Society B |volume=277 |pages=679–688 |doi=10.1098/rspb.2009.1155 |ref={{harvid|Jorgensen et al|2010}} |pmc=2842735 }} [http://gtopp.org/images/stories/publications/Jorgensen_et_al_rspb200911551.pdf direct PDF link]
== External links == * [http://whitesharkcafe.org/ Voyage to the White Shark Café], website for the 2018 expedition aboard ''Falkor'' * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070929101932/http://www.topp.org/species/white_shark/ Tagging of Pacific Predators: White Sharks], part of the [[Census of Marine Life]] * [https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B003DZ1UGM/ White Shark Cafe - The Film], a documentary about the White Shark Café
